summary: post-translational modifications (PTMs) involve the addition of a chemical group to the protein after it has been generated by the translational machinery. a large number of PTMs such as phosphorylation [1], methylation [2], acetylation [3], and glycosylation [4] are known and they regulate various biol processes. the SUMO protein forms an isopeptide bond with substrate proteins. sumoylation is catalyzed by SUMO ligases such as protein inhibitor of activated STAT (PIAS), Ran-bingding protein 2 (RanBP2), or human PcG protein Pc2. reticuloendotheliosis viral oncogene homolog A of Bombyx mori (BmRelA) remains unknown. a proteomic approach is reported for identification of substrates modified by SUMOylation. this shed light on the crucial process of protein sumoylation in B. mori. pre-immune serum was used as the primary antibody. the nuclei were stained with 4',6-diamidino-2-phenylindol (DAPI) the samples were viewed using a laser fluorescence microscope. eGFP-SUMO and ubiquitin carrier protein 9 were expressed in baculovirus vectors and subjected to GFP immunoprecipitation. the immunoprecipitated proteins were then separated by SDS-PAGE and subjected to western blot analysis. the isolated SUMOylated proteins from eGFP-SUMO and BmUBC9 preparation were identified by LC–ESI-MS/MS. protein ID Description Number of Peptides BGIBMGA000115-PA BUD13 homolog 2 Drosophila S2 cells. cells were processed for immunoprecipitation with anti-Flag magnetic beads. cells were analyzed by western blotting using anti-His antibody. the majority of the proteins were functionally categorized to GO terms. under the “biological process” category, the proteins were involved in “cellular process” (19.39%), “metabolic process” (16.48%), “single organism process” (9.2%), and “biological regulation” (8.05%). under the “cellular component” category, the identified proteins were mainly involved in “binding” and “catalytic activity” (35.8%) a special baculovirus vector can express foreign proteins under different promoters. the control construct could express eGFP-SUMO, but lacked BmUbc9. the results confirm that the SUMO-Ubc9 fusion construct could be useful. eGFP-Bmsumo and PIAS were found to coimmunoprecipitate in the presence of eGFP-Bmubc9 and eGFP-sumo plus BmUbc9. some of the homologous proteins identified in this study have been previously reported to be SUMOylated. recombinant baculovirus of B. mori nucleopolyhedrovirus (BmNPV) was used to express eGFP-sumo plus BmUbc9. some viral proteins such as the chicken embryo lethal orphan adenovirus Gam1 protein [42,43], the human papillomavirus (HPV) E6 protein [44,45] and the Epstein-Barr virus (LMP1) [48] can 203 proteins identified with one or more peptides, 74% contained at least one SUMOylation site, and 13% contained at least one SUMO-interaction Motifs (SIM) adenovirus early region 1B 55-kDa protein (E1B-55K) protein were also identified. immunofluorescence analysis was carried out using a confocal laser fluorescence microscope. fluorescence was observed across the entire cell but appeared as aggregated dots in the nucleus. SUMO is found to be enriched in the nuclei of cultured Drosophila S2 and pole cells. eGFP-SUMO, eGFP-SUMO and ubiquitin carrier protein 9 were isolated with anti-GFP microbeads. the eluate was subjected to SDS-PAGE followed by western blotting with an anti-GFP antibody. d proteins were electrophoresed for a short time on SDS-PAGE. the bands were cut and processed for LC–ESI-MS/MS analysis. in total, 68 proteins that were identified by two or more peptides were considered candidates for SUMOylation. thiol peroxiredoxin 2 BGIBMGA002620-PA predicted: sequestosome-1-like isoform X2 3 a role in metabolism, spliceosome and ribosome functions, and in RNA transport showed the highest number of matches. no fluorescence was detected in BmN cells. the cells were treated with anti-BmSUMO antibody. the fluorescent signal was developed by incubating the nuclei. eGFP, eGFP-SUMO and ubiquitin carrier protein 9 were expressed in baculovirus vectors and subjected to GFP immunoprecipitation. the immunoprecipitated proteins were then separated by SDS-PAGE and subjected to western blot analysis. Bm_nscaf2970_ flag-tagged SUMO and His-tagged candidates were co-expressed in Drosophila S2 cells. cell lysates were immunoprecipitated with anti-Flag magnetic beads and analyzed by western blotting using anti-His antibody. resultant proteins were functionally categorized based on universal gene ontology (GO) annotation terms. the majority of the proteins (59 of 68) were functionally categorized to GO terms. under the “biological process” category, the proteins were involved in “cellular process” (19.39%), “metabolic process” (16.48%), “single organism process” (9.2%), and “biological regulation” (8.05%). the SUMO-Ubc9 fusion protein has a higher conjugating activity for SIM-containing targets such as Sp100 and human cytomegalovirus immediate-early 2 (IE2) protein [26]. the control construct that could express eGFP-SUMO, but lacked BmUbc9, was also used for immunoprecipition. some homologous proteins identified in this study have been previously reported to be SUMOylated. for example, the endoplasmic reticulum-resident chaperone calreticulin is known to be sumoylated. the endoribonuclease Dicer, which cleaves the stem-loop structure from pre-miRNAs, has also been shown to be SUMOylated. several ribosomal proteins and HSPs have been identified as SUMOylation substrates. recombinant baculovirus of B. mori nucleopolyhedrovirus (BmNPV) was used to express eGFP-sumo plus BmUbc9. some viruses encode sumoylation mimicking enzymes, such as the Kaposi’s sarcoma-associated herpes virus (KSHV) K-bZIP protein and the adenovirus early region 1B 55-kDa protein (E1B-55K) protein. infection of Spodoptera frugiperda cells by AcMNPV leads to a decrease in the amount of free SUMO, coupled with an increase in the amount of SUMO- the Bmsumo gene was amplified with the forward primer BmsumoF (5'-GTCGACgctgatgaaagaaggga-3') and the reverse primer BmsumoR (5'-CTGCAGttactccccggtgctg-3') the recombinant bacmid eGFP-Bmsumo + BmUbc9 was transfected into BmN cells for amplification. cells were lysed with 1 mL ice-cold lysis buffer (150 mM NaCl, 1% Triton X-100, 50 mM Tris–HCl (pH 8.0), 10 mM N-Ethylmaleimide (NEM) and 1 protease inhibitor cocktail. the incubated mixtures were then applied onto the column and washed with 10 200 L washing buffer 1 (150 mM NaCl, 1% Western Blotting Aliquots of each input lysate and both the eGFP-Bmsumo + BmUbc9 and control preparations were subjected to SDS-PAGE. the protein samples were transferred onto a PVDF membrane (Immobilon-P, Millipore, Merck KGaA, Darmstadt, Germany) after electrophoresis, the membrane was washed three times with PBS-T for 5 min. the cells were washed three times with 1 PBS and fixed in methanol:acetone (1:1) on ice for 15 min. the cells were then incubated with protein-G fused with enhanced green fluorescent protein (eGFP) and stained with the nucleus-specific stain DAPI (Sigma, Shanghai, China) 10 L of the supernatant was loaded onto a 2-cm C18 trap column in a LC-20AD nanoHPLC (Shimadzu, Kyoto, Japan) by using the autosampler. the samples were loaded at 8 L/min for 4 min, followed by a 2-min linear gradient to 80% buffer B. ion count of 20,000 in the MS survey scan with a dynamic exclusion duration of 15 s. automatic gain control (AGC) was used to optimize the spectra generated by the Orbitrap. m/z scan range was 350 to 2000 Da. all PCR fragments were inserted into pMT/V5-His B vector. 1 107 of S2 cells were transfected with 1 g of each SUMO and SUMOyalation candidate constructions. 0.5 mM CuSO4 was added to the medium to induce protein expression. raw data files acquired from the Orbitrap were converted into MGF files using Proteome Discoverer 1.2 (PD 1.2, Thermo, Pittsburgh, PA, USA) for protein identification, a mass tolerance of 20 ppm was permitted for intact peptide masses. the BmUbc9 gene was amplified with the forward primer BmsumoF (5'-GTCGACgctgatgaaagaagggaaggga-3') and the reverse primer BmsumoR (5'-CTGCAGttactcccctgctg-3') the fragments were cloned into a modified pFastBac Dual vector (Invitrogen, Carlsbad, CA, USA cells were lysed with 1 mL ice-cold lysis buffer (150 mM NaCl, 1% Triton X-100, 50 mM Tris–HCl (pH 8.0), 10 mM N-Ethylmaleimide (NEM) and 1 protease inhibitor cocktail. cell supernatants were collected and incubated with 50 L anti-GFP MicroBeads for 30 min on ice. Western Blotting Aliquots of each input lysate and both the eGFP-Bmsumo + BmUbc9 and control preparations were subjected to SDS-PAGE. the protein samples were transferred onto a PVDF membrane (Immobilon-P, Millipore, Merck KGaA, Darmstadt, Germany) by using the Trans-Blot Cell apparatus (Bio-Rad, Shanghai, China) the membrane was washed three times with the cells were washed three times with 1 PBS and fixed in methanol:acetone (1:1) on ice for 15 min. the cells were then incubated with protein-G fused with enhanced green fluorescent protein (eGFP) and stained with the nucleus-specific stain DAPI (Sigma, Shanghai, China) for 1 h. 10 L of the supernatant was loaded onto a 2-cm C18 trap column in a LC-20AD nanoHPLC (Shimadzu, Kyoto, Japan) the samples were loaded at 8 L/min for 4 min. gradient of 2% to 35% buffer B was run for 44 min at 300 nL/min. automatic gain control (AGC) was used to optimize the spectra generated by the Orbitrap. the target for full MS was 3 106 and 1 105 for MS2. all PCR fragments were inserted into pMT/V5-His B vector. 1 107 of S2 cells were transfected with 1 g of each SUMO and SUMOyalation candidate constructions. cells were collected and washed with PBS. raw data files acquired from the Orbitrap were converted into MGF files. protein identification was performed using the Mascot search engine. a mass tolerance of 20 ppm was permitted for intact peptide masses. 68 candidate SUMOylated proteins identified from the proteome. 59 proteins were functionally categorized to GO terms. KEGG pathways analysis showed 46 proteins involved in 76 pathways.
